content.description: This one gets the most stars in the book.  The crux is the start, getting to and moving past the first bolt on thin holds.  Then some very cool knobs on a steep section, with an easier featured slab to finish.  Maybe worth a 3rd star if it had hangers.Be extremely careful scrambling to the top of this tower from the left tower, to set an anchor! It's loose and sketchy.
content.protection: 5 hangerless bolts to a 2-bolt hangerless anchor. Book says to bring a #2 Friend as well (that's a #1 camalot for the kids these days, I'm not sure how necessary it is as I was on TR solo). If the bolts had hangers, a stick-clip might be a good idea to get to the first bolt as well. As long as the bolts are hangerless, anchor with a cordelette slung around the pinnacle at the top of the tower.
content.location: Left bolt line on the right tower

content.description: The face climb on the right side of the left tower.  Felt hardest down low, up high you can grab the right arete.  Guidebook called it "very loose", I didn't think it was bad.  Maybe worth a 2nd star if it had hangers.
content.protection: 5 bolts (hangerless); 2 bolt anchor (hangerless).  The book says to supplement this with small cams; I don't know if you need them (I was on TR solo).  As long as the climb remains hangerless, anchor off a cordelette around a large block at the top of the formation.
content.location: The bolted line on the left tower.

climbs.name: Mommy, May I Eat the Worm?

content.description: This is the seam on the left tower. Crux is down low, but interesting throughout.  A nice-looking line, just a bit too short.  Would be a scary lead with thin pro on Capulin-esque rock.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5" .  Anchor using a cordelette slung around the large blocks on top of the tower.
content.location: Obvious seam on the left tower.

content.description: Entrance Tower is more like 2 towers, with 2 routes on the left and 3 on the right. It's the first cliff on the right side as you hike up LA Canyon  and has 5 routes. About 50' tall; the rock is tuff and was better quality than expected (if they were at Las Conchas, they'd get climbed and people wouldn't complain too much, but are by no means mega-classic). South-facing, sunny.  A short uphill bushwhacking gets to the base. Currently (2021) all bolts on all climbs are missing hangers, including anchors. As a result, you'll need to get to the top to set an anchor, which is annoying and a seriously sketchy scramble (be super careful! I went up the left side but there may be an easier longer way).These are written up in Jemez Rock.  Word is Shibli bolted these but later pulled the hangers so as to do other routes.  I didn't sense any obvious access issues or feel like I was unlawfully sneaking around.
